Award.AwardTitle: Conference: International Ciliate Molecular Biology Conference, July 10-16, 2015 in Camerino, Italy

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support attendance by postdoctoral fellows and graduate students at the International Conference on Ciliate Molecular Biology, to be held July 10-16, 2015 in Camerino, Italy. In keeping with a long-standing priority for this conference, participation by young researchers and under-represented minorities, including women, will be emphasized. The conference will offer opportunities for sharing latest research results in both formal and informal settings, and thus will provide an ideal environment for building scientific networks and collaboration.

This biannual meeting is the major convocation of experimental biologists working with ciliated protozoa, and plays a critical role in sustaining the vitality of this important research community. The participants are members of an array of discipline-specific fields, including cell biology, molecular evolution, structural biology, cell signaling, and nucleic acid biochemistry. The objectives of this meeting are to (i) disseminate new research information and ideas, (ii) share technical innovations, (iii) organize further development of community resources, and (iv) enhance graduate and undergraduate research and education initiatives. This conference will contain workshops on Future Directions and Ciliates in the Classroom, several platform sessions on the new and exciting research areas in the field of Ciliate Molecular Biology, and two poster sessions. Of note will be a session on genome evolution and adaptation, which will emphasize the application of computational approaches to study gene and genome evolution. Other sessions will feature additional examples of the application of new technologies to unravel molecular and cellular details of this fascinating group of organisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Conference on Ciliate Molecular Biology attracted investigators from the United States, Europe and Asia to present recent scientific discoveries, share resources and enhance graduate and undergraduate research training. Despite the small size of the ciliate community studies of these organisms has led to key discoveries in several fields including self-splicing RNAs, telomeres and telomerase, histone modifications, and epigenetic chromatin remodeling. The 2015 meeting highlighted ciliates as models for the study of genome evolution, non-Mendelian inheritance and their roles in environmental adaptation. The meeting included sessions on ciliate genome evolution, the analysis of DNA elimination during formation of the somatic macronucleus and the role of small RNAs in genome rearrangements. Additional sessions focused on mechanistic analysis of chromatin, basal bodies, cilia and cell signaling pathways. The meeting closed with a session on ciliates as models for environmental stress and the symbiotic relationships between ciliates and prokaryotes. The keynote speaker, Richard Davis (U. of Colorado), presented research on programmed DNA elimination in nematodes, thus providing a broader context for the analysis of genome remodeling in ciliates.

A three-hour workshop was devoted to using ciliates in undergraduate laboratory courses that emphasize independent research followed by presentations of undergraduate research projects. Eight undergraduates representing the United States, Italy and Canada presented their research and received suggestions and encouragement from independent scientists. Three poster sessions provided significant opportunities for discussion and collaborative planning between research groups.

Over 120 scientists representing 14 countries attended including participants from Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Poland, Russia, Turkey, India and China and the United States. The meeting was co-sponsored by the European Cooperation in Science and Technology (COST) with additional support from the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS)-promoted GDRE research network entitled "Paramecium Genome Dynamics and Evolution”.  More than 40% of the participants were women and six of twelve sessions were chaired or co-chaired by women scientists.  NSF funds supported the attendance of undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral scientists from United States laboratories. As a result of this conference several research groups shared unpublished data, cell lines and developed collaborative efforts.
